issue.title: [ENH] Using Kotsu as a benchmarking framework - Implementation in sktime

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Reference Issue #2777
Kotsu is a high level and light-weight package that performs benchmarking that has no dependency on specific packages. At a high level, it allows users to register a dataset with a validation task (CV splitter method) and then apply estimators to that registration. It will be beneficial to investigate its application to sktime's benchmarking.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Input: estimator, dataset, cross validation splitter
Output: a Dataframe showing result per estimator per dataset
*: In this notebook, the result is returned as a .csv saved to the same folder as the notebook

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N/A

**Additional context**
N/A

body:
Hi, developer of `kotsu` here :wave:. 

Just wanted to drop a note to say we would be stoked if `kotsu` was a useful tool for `sktime` benchmarking. 

We use it for model benchmarking and validation on all our client projects, nearly always using it with `sklearn`-like model interfaces. We've tried to keep `kotsu` as light-weight as possible, but we have a few very common patterns we use whenever using `kotsu` with `sklearn` which we will likely add into `kotsu` in the future - happy to share them in advance if helpful. 

If any questions arise do fire away and we'll answer them. 

We would be game to contribute some of our time to doing a spike with `kotsu` to see if it will be a good fit for what you're trying to achieve if you'd like to point me in the direction of an example benchmark you're trying to implement. Also open to taking features requests from you co. if there's pieces missing etc.

@DBCerigo (also FYI @TNTran92, @ltsaprounis), we're basically tring to set up benchmarking functionality for things similar to "run the M4 or M5 competition with a specific set of estimators", or "perform rolling window backtesting with these estimators", or "replicate the time series classification bake-off with these estimators.

There is some historic work in `sktime`:

* in 2019/2020, @mloning recreated the M4/M5 competition for the `sktime` paper with a few methods. I don't think he ever shared the code, though. I don't think I have access to it, for instance.
* in 2019, @TonyBagnall also wanted to replicate his benchmarking studies from earlier papers, most prominently, the "time series classification bake-off". I think he never did that either, but there must be some code that his research group is using. I find it unlikely that we'll get access or that that moves into `sktime`. But being able to do sth similar would be a nice goal.
Some historical discussion here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/12 it looks like the topic just got ghosted in the end.
* the benchmarking module of `sktime`, which I think still works but has run out of sync a bit, design-wise https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/main/sktime/benchmarking. @ViktorKaz wanted to work on this but that also got abandoned.

In summary, it seems that benchmarking is a topic which seems at the same time hard design-wise, and a topic where people are either reluctant or unable to share or produce clean, reusable code.
Maybe this is where `kotsu` (or openML etc) could help?

The "application" goals for me would be clear:

* few-liner to run M4/M5 like benchmarks for forecasting
* few-liner to run bake-off like benchmarks for classification

(and it should be flexible to change the data sets used, the metrics used, the estimators used)

issue.title: [ENH] Using OpenML as a benchmarking framework - Implementation in sktime

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Refer to #2777 

OpenML is a benchmarking framework that allows ML experiments to be reproduced easily and transparently. Each dataset and task has a unique ID that is share-able, allowing other users to repeat the same task on the same dataset. At the moment, it has limited support for time series dataset. It will be beneficial to investigate its potential to host sktime's dataset and our benchmark tasks.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A demonstration of implementation of sktime to OpenML. Or demonstration why it is not possible.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Kotsu #2804 and Gluon-ts

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

issue.title: OpenML application to sktime

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Solution to Issue #2821. See also Issue #2777

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Demonstrate how OpenML's data format is incompatible with sktime.

TLDR:
- In an OpenML dataset, each variable is in a column, each time point is a row, just like in a DataFrame.
- Correction from daily stand-up: Not required to have `target` column but since OpenML does not support Pd.Series inside DataFrame => Need to turn time series into rolling-window format.
- Because dataset has to be rolling window, adapters need to be made for .ts format, estimator, CV splitter and `metrics`
- Still not sure how to make a 1:1 conversion of MultiIndex DataFrame to OpenML Dataset 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->
Yes, OpenML

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

Performance, design and viability of implementing OpenML in sktime

#### Any other comments?

Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.

body:
TLDR:
In the order of most  to least work
OpenML -> gluon-ts -> kotsu

- kotsu works straight out of the box - we do not have to worry about adapters and just on how to incorporate it into sktime
- Both OpenML and gluon-ts require adapters for dataset, estimator and `metrics.` OpenML doesn't support MultiIndex and will require a major investment if we want to go with it. Gluonts may not help us as a benchmarking framework but it has DL models and other tool that willl be nice-to-have.

@fkiraly 
> @DBCerigo (also FYI @TNTran92, @ltsaprounis), we're basically tring to set up benchmarking functionality for things similar to "run the M4 or M5 competition with a specific set of estimators", or "perform rolling window backtesting with these estimators", or "replicate the time series classification bake-off with these estimators.

`kotsu` was designed exactly to do these things, with the following properties of minimizing bloat or overhead, allowing for any model interface/validation, and avoiding common pitfalls when aiming for fair benchmarks  [ref](https://github.com/datavaluepeople/kotsu#what-is-it). 

"run the M4 or M5 competition", and "perform rolling window backtesting" would be a `validation`s and each estimator would be a `model`. Register them and "hit" `run`. 

> In summary, it seems that benchmarking is a topic which seems at the same time hard design-wise, and a topic where people are either reluctant or unable to share or produce clean, reusable code. Maybe this is where `kotsu` (or openML etc) could help?

Again, we built `kotsu` specifically to solve those problems of benchmarking often becoming a messy, bloated, and even inaccurate (unfair comparisons) endeavours. 

> (and it should be flexible to change the data sets used, the metrics used, the estimators used)

Yep it is designed for such flexibility. 

@TNTran92 
> kotsu works straight out of the box - we do not have to worry about adapters and just on how to incorporate it into sktime

Glad to hear that.

From https://github.com/TNTran92/sktime/blob/kotsu_application/sktime/benchmarking/kotsu_sktime_application.ipynb it looks like you already know what you're doing.


Myself and co (@ali-tny @alex-hh) would be interested in contributing to/supporting on implementing such benchmarking. We use it for all our projects and so can offer our usual patterns/structure for using it in a clean and unobtrusive way. 

Are there any time constraints or aimed-for deadlines for this?
